TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed BitmapCacheBrush extends System.Windows.Media.Brush

Docs.summary: Paints an area with cached content.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the BitmapCacheBrush class to reuse a cached element efficiently. This is useful when you need to paint complex content onto multiple elements. Use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache> class to cache a complex element.
Assign a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.Target%2A> property and optionally assign a <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache> to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.BitmapCache%2A> property. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.CacheMode> of the brush and the target <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual> interact to produce different behaviors. The following table describes this interaction.
||Target has no CacheMode|Target has CacheMode| |-|-----------------------------|--------------------------| |Brush has no CacheMode|Target visual renders normally; brush uses default cache behavior.|Target visual renders into its own cache; brush uses targetâ€™s cache when rendering.| |Brush has CacheMode|Target visual renders normally; brush renders target into its own cache and uses this to render.|Target visual renders into its own cache; brush renders target into brush's own cache and uses this to render.|
The BitmapCacheBrush class is similar to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.VisualBrush> class, but BitmapCacheBrush always renders from a cache on the target element, or from a cache defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.BitmapCache%2A> property. The BitmapCacheBrush class also supports dirty regions.
The following table shows the default bitmap cache settings for the BitmapCacheBrush class.
|Bitmap Cache Property|Default Setting| |---------------------------|---------------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.SnapsToDevicePixels%2A>|`false`| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.EnableClearType%2A>|`false`| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.RenderAtScale%2A>|1|
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.SnapsToDevicePixels%2A> property is ignored by the BitmapCacheBrush class.
The BitmapCacheBrush class ignores the following properties on the root <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual>. This behavior differs from the <xref:System.Windows.Media.VisualBrush> class.
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualOffset%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualTransform%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualClip%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualEffect%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualOpacity%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Media.Visual.VisualOpacityMask%2A>
## Examples The following code example shows how to associate a <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache> with a BitmapCacheBrush. You can use the BitmapCacheBrush resource on multiple elements and achieve good performance. For the complete code listing, see [How to: Use a Cached Element as a Brush](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
[!code-xml[System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush#_BitmapCacheBrushCreation](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/bitmapcachebrushdemo/window1.xaml#_bitmapcachebrushcreation)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the AutoLayoutContent property is `true`, layout is applied to the contents of the brush if <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.Target%2A> is a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> with no parent.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The BitmapCache property interacts with the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush.Target%2A> property. For a table that shows this interaction, see the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCacheBrush> class overview.
